expanded_description: This section introduces position-time graphs, a fundamental tool for visualizing and analyzing motion. These graphs show how an object's position changes over time, and their features reveal key information about velocity and type of motion.

core_concept.principle: A position-time graph (x-t graph) plots an object's position on the vertical axis against time on the horizontal axis. The shape of the graph reveals how the object is moving, and the slope at any point gives the velocity.
core_concept.explanation: Position-time graphs provide a visual representation of motion that makes it easy to see where an object is at any time, whether it is moving or at rest, how fast it is moving, and whether its velocity is constant or changing.

image.alt: Basic position-time graph showing position on y-axis and time on x-axis with several lines of different slopes
image.caption: Position-time graphs show how position changes over time; slope equals velocity

sections.introduction: A position-time graph is a powerful way to represent motion visually. By plotting position versus time, we can see at a glance how an object's location changes.

key_concept.definition: A position-time graph is a graph with time (t) on the horizontal axis (x-axis) and position (x) on the vertical axis (y-axis). Each point on the graph represents the object's position at a specific time.
key_concept.context: These graphs allow us to analyze motion without doing calculations first. The shape of the line tells us about the object's velocity and whether it is constant or changing.

principles.statement: Time is always the independent variable on the x-axis; position is the dependent variable on the y-axis.
principles.application: Each axis must be labeled with the quantity and units (e.g., Time (s), Position (m)).
principles.example: A point at (3 s, 10 m) means the object was at position 10 meters at time 3 seconds.

principles.statement: Every point on the graph tells you where the object was at a particular instant.
principles.application: To find position at a given time, locate the time on the x-axis, go up to the curve, and read the position on the y-axis.
principles.example: On a graph, at t = 2 s, the curve shows x = 5 m, so the object was at 5 m at that moment.

sections.introduction: The most important feature of a position-time graph is its slope. The slope tells us how fast the position is changing - which is exactly what velocity measures.

key_concept.definition: The slope of a position-time graph equals the velocity of the object. For a straight-line segment, slope = rise/run = Δx/Δt = average velocity. For a curved graph, the slope at a point (tangent) gives instantaneous velocity.
key_concept.context: This relationship makes position-time graphs invaluable: they provide a direct visual representation of velocity.

principles.statement: On a position-time graph, velocity is the rate at which position changes, which is exactly the slope: $v = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \text{slope}$.
principles.application: Calculate slope by choosing two points on the line and dividing the change in position by the change in time.
principles.example: A line from (0 s, 2 m) to (4 s, 10 m) has slope = $(10-2)/(4-0) = 8/4 = 2 \text{ m/s}$. This means velocity is 2 m/s.

principles.statement: The steeper the slope, the greater the speed. A shallow slope means slow speed; a horizontal line means zero velocity (at rest).
principles.application: Compare slopes visually: steeper line = faster motion.
principles.example: A line with slope 5 m/s is steeper than one with slope 2 m/s, indicating greater speed.

principles.statement: A positive slope means positive velocity (moving in positive direction). A negative slope means negative velocity (moving in negative direction).
principles.application: The sign of the slope tells you which way the object is moving relative to your chosen sign convention.
principles.example: A line sloping downward (negative slope) means the object is moving in the negative direction (its position is decreasing).

characteristics: Positive slope: moving in positive direction
Negative slope: moving in negative direction
classifications.behavior: The slope directly gives velocity, so any change in slope indicates a change in velocity (acceleration). Constant slope means constant velocity.

examples.explanation: Line rising to the right → position increasing → positive velocity
Line falling to the right → position decreasing → negative velocity
Horizontal line → position constant → object at rest

worked_examples.title: Finding Velocity from Slope
worked_examples.problem: A position-time graph shows a straight line passing through (1 s, 4 m) and (6 s, 19 m). Find the velocity.
worked_examples.concept_applied: For a straight line on an x-t graph, slope = velocity = Δx/Δt.

image.alt: Position-time graph with slope triangle showing rise (Δx) and run (Δt)
image.caption: Slope on a position-time graph equals velocity

sections.introduction: Position-time graphs can take various shapes, each revealing different types of motion. Recognizing these shapes helps quickly understand how an object is moving.

classifications.behavior: The object moves at steady speed in one direction. Equal time intervals produce equal position changes.

examples.explanation: Object moves in positive direction at constant speed (e.g., 2 m/s).
Object moves in negative direction at constant speed (e.g., -3 m/s).
Object at rest at constant position.

classifications.behavior: The object's velocity is changing. The steepness of the curve indicates how fast velocity changes.

examples.explanation: Slope getting steeper → velocity increasing in positive direction → positive acceleration.
Slope getting less steep or more negative → velocity decreasing in positive direction or increasing in negative direction → acceleration opposite to initial velocity.

principles.statement: If the graph is curved, the slope is changing, which means velocity is changing - the object is accelerating.
principles.application: The direction of curvature tells whether acceleration is positive or negative relative to the motion.
principles.example: A graph that gets steeper as time increases means the object is speeding up (velocity increasing).

principles.statement: On a curved graph, the instantaneous velocity at any time is the slope of the tangent line at that point.
principles.application: Draw a tangent line at the point of interest and calculate its slope.
principles.example: At the peak of a curved graph, the tangent is horizontal → instantaneous velocity = 0.

worked_examples.title: Interpreting Graph Shape
worked_examples.problem: Describe the motion represented by each segment of a position-time graph: (a) straight line sloping up, (b) horizontal line, (c) straight line sloping down, (d) curve getting steeper upward.

step_by_step.explanation: Straight line sloping up → constant positive velocity → moving in positive direction at constant speed.
Horizontal line → zero slope → object at rest.
Straight line sloping down → constant negative velocity → moving in negative direction at constant speed.
Curve getting steeper upward → slope increasing → velocity increasing in positive direction → positive acceleration.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) constant positive velocity, (b) at rest, (c) constant negative velocity, (d) speeding up in positive direction
worked_examples.concept_applied: Graph shape reveals type of motion: straight lines = constant velocity; curves = changing velocity; slope direction = direction of motion.

image.alt: Position-time graphs showing different shapes: constant positive, constant negative, zero slope, curved upward, curved downward
image.caption: Different graph shapes represent different types of motion

sections.introduction: Position-time graphs also allow us to find displacement directly by reading positions at different times.

key_concept.definition: Displacement between two times is the change in position: $\Delta x = x(t_2) - x(t_1)$. On a graph, this is the vertical difference between the two corresponding points.
key_concept.context: While slope gives velocity, the vertical separation gives displacement. Both pieces of information are available from the same graph.

principles.statement: To find displacement between $t_1$ and $t_2$, read the positions $x_1$ and $x_2$ from the graph and subtract: $x_2 - x_1$.
principles.application: The sign of the result tells the direction of displacement.
principles.example: At t=2 s, x=5 m; at t=5 s, x=11 m; displacement = 11-5 = +6 m.

principles.statement: The graph shows position at all times, so you can find both net displacement (final - initial) and total distance by tracking path length.
principles.application: For distance, you must account for any back-and-forth motion by adding absolute changes.
principles.example: If position goes 5 m forward then 3 m back, displacement = 2 m, but distance = 8 m. The graph would show the reversal.

worked_examples.title: Finding Displacement from a Graph
worked_examples.problem: On a position-time graph, at t = 2 s the position is 4 m, and at t = 7 s the position is -6 m. Find the displacement over this interval.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Displacement is final position minus initial position, read directly from graph.

sections.introduction: Understanding common errors helps students correctly interpret position-time graphs.

classifications.type: Confusing the Graph with a Picture of the Path
classifications.value: Thinking the graph shows the actual path of motion, not position vs. time
characteristics: Believing upward slope means uphill motion
Thinking the shape matches the trajectory
Misinterpreting curved graphs as curved paths
classifications.behavior: A position-time graph is not a map of the path. The vertical axis is position, not height above ground. A straight line means constant velocity, not motion on a hill.

examples.explanation: Student sees upward slope and thinks object is going uphill.
Upward slope means position increasing over time - moving in positive direction, regardless of actual terrain.

classifications.value: Confusing steepness with speed sign or misreading slope
characteristics: Not recognizing zero slope as rest
Confusing steeper with faster in wrong direction
classifications.behavior: Steepness indicates magnitude of velocity (speed), regardless of sign. A steep negative slope means fast motion in negative direction.

examples.explanation: Seeing a steep negative slope and saying object is moving slowly because slope is negative.
Steep negative slope means large speed in negative direction.

classifications.value: Using graph coordinates incorrectly for slope
characteristics: Using points not on the line (for best-fit)
classifications.behavior: Slope must be rise/run (Δx/Δt). Reversing gives the reciprocal, which has wrong units and meaning.

examples.explanation: For Δx = 10 m, Δt = 5 s, calculating slope = 5/10 = 0.5 (wrong units and value).

image.alt: Illustrations of common mistakes: confusing graph with path, slope errors
image.caption: Common errors include misinterpreting what the graph represents and slope calculation mistakes

summary: Position-time graphs are essential tools for visualizing and analyzing motion. They plot position on the y-axis against time on the x-axis. The slope of the graph at any point equals the velocity: $v = \Delta x/\Delta t = \text{slope}$. A straight line indicates constant velocity (zero acceleration), with positive slope meaning motion in the positive direction, negative slope meaning motion in the negative direction, and zero slope (horizontal line) meaning the object is at rest. A curved line indicates changing velocity (acceleration). The steepness of the graph indicates speed: steeper means faster. Displacement between two times is found by subtracting the initial position from the final position read from the graph. Common mistakes include confusing the graph with the actual path of motion, misinterpreting negative slopes as slow motion, and calculating slope incorrectly. Mastering position-time graph interpretation is fundamental to understanding kinematics and prepares students for velocity-time and acceleration-time graphs.
